comment._content: Background information only on 6/4429 Private Thomas Bullough. The 1911 census has an approximate match, born 1891, in Middlesbrough. 1/6 Durham Light Infantry was raised around Bishop Auckland in August 1914 and was initially mustered at Boldon Colliery, Co Durham, between Hebburn and Sunderland. The Battalion moved to another colliery at Ravenworth Park Drift outside Newcastle in October. On 17th April 1915 they arrived at Boulogne as part of 151st Brigade in 50th Northumbrian Division. 151st Brigade consisted 1/6, 1/7, 1/8 and 1/9 Battalions of the Durham Light Infantry. In April 1915 151st Brigade fought in the successful defence of Ypres at the Second Battle of Ypres as the Germans attempted to break through the Allied lines. 1/6 and 1/8 DLI suffered such heavy casualties (1/8 DLI lost 19 officers and 574 ORs) that on 3 Jun 1915 they were briefly merged to be 6/8 DLI before replacements arrived and 1/6 Battalion was reconstituted. During the Battle of the Somme, 151st Brigade was an assaulting formation at the Battle of Flers Courcelette, 15-22 Sep 1916, including the capture of Martinpuich. There is excellent information on this battle, including images of original battle maps, at the 4th Northumberland Fusiliers website at: www.4thbnnf.com/35_160915_flerscourcelette.html .//

comment._content: Thomas Bullough of 42 Linden Grove, Linthorpe, Middlesborough. Son of John Thomas and Margaret Hannah Bullough. He enlisted in 1st/6th Durhams at The Drill Hall, Bishop Auckland, probably on or shortly after 4th August 1914. He was killed in action on 18th September 1916 during fighting at Hook Trench near Mametz Wood. He is commemorated on the Middlesborough War Memorial. Details were compiled by Mr Robert Coulson at www.ww1-yorkshires.org.uk/pdf-files/bob%20coulson/mbro-wa...
